Group.title: Uncommon Network Protocols
Group.description: The system includes support for several network protocols which are not commonly used. Although security vulnerabilities in kernel networking code are not frequently discovered, the consequences can be dramatic. Ensuring uncommon network protocols are disabled reduces the system's risk to attacks targeted at its implementation of those protocols.
Group.warning: Although these protocols are not commonly used, avoid disruption in your network environment by ensuring they are not needed prior to disabling them.

Rule.title: Disable DCCP Support
Rule.description: The Datagram Congestion Control Protocol (DCCP) is a relatively new transport layer protocol, designed to support streaming media and telephony.
Rule.rationale: Disabling DCCP protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation.

Rule.title: Disable SCTP Support
Rule.description: The Stream Control Transmission Protocol (SCTP) is a transport layer protocol, designed to support the idea of message-oriented communication, with several streams of messages within one connection.
Rule.rationale: Disabling SCTP protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation.

Rule.title: Disable RDS Support
Rule.description: The Reliable Datagram Sockets (RDS) protocol is a transport layer protocol designed to provide reliable high- bandwidth, low-latency communications between nodes in a cluster.
Rule.rationale: Disabling RDS protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation.

Rule.title: Disable TIPC Support
Rule.description: The Transparent Inter-Process Communication (TIPC) protocol is designed to provide communications between nodes in a cluster.
Rule.rationale: Disabling TIPC protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation.

Rule.title: Disable AppleTalk Support
Rule.description: The AppleTalk suite of protocols is no longer in common use. Binding this protocol to the network stack increases the attack surface of the host. Unprivileged local processes may be able to cause the system to dynamically load a protocol handler by opening a socket using the protocol.
Rule.rationale: Disabling AppleTalk protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation.

Rule.title: Disable Network Bridging Support
Rule.description: Some systems have the ability to bridge or switch frames (link-layer forwarding) between multiple interfaces. This can be useful in a variety of situations but, if enabled when not needed, has the potential to bypass network partitioning and security.
Rule.rationale: Disabling network bridging protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation.

Rule.title: Disable IEEE1394 (Firewire) Support
Rule.description: Firewire is a common computer peripheral interface. Firewire devices may include storage devices with the potential to install malicious software on a system or exfiltrate data.
Rule.rationale: Disabling IEEE1394 (Firewire) protects the system against exploitation of any flaws in its implementation.
